messageBody:
--- Brian Button <bbutton01@...> wrote:
> Tests that share the same setUp and tearDown logic should be in the
> same TestCase. Those that do not should be in other TestCase-derived
> classes.

1. This leads to some possibly solutions for the OP's problem:

public abstract class CommonTests extends TestCase {
public void testOne() {
// test that uses configurable
}
protected Object configurable = null;
}

public class ConfigurationOneTest extends CommonTests {
public void setUp() throws Exception {
super.setUp();
configurable = // create for configuration 1....
}
}

public class ConfigurationTwoTest extends CommonTests {
public void setUp() throws Exception {
super.setUp();
configurable = // create for configuration 2....
}
}

2. Here is another solution:


public abstract class CommonTests extends TestCase {
protected abstract Object getConfigurable();

public void testOne() {
Object configurable = getConfigurable();
// test that uses configurable
}
}

public class ConfigurationOneTest extends CommonTests {
protected abstract Object getConfigurable() {
Object currentConfig = // create for configuration 1....
}
}

public class ConfigurationTwoTest extends CommonTests {
protected abstract Object getConfigurable() {
Object currentConfig = // create for configuration 1....
}
}

3. Or combine 1 and 2, by having setUp defined in CommonTests call
getConfigurable() which is overridden by the subclasses:

public abstract class CommonTests extends TestCase {
protected abstract Object getConfigurable();

public void setUp() throws Exception {
super.setUp();
configurable = getConfigurable();
}

public void testOne() {
// test that uses configurable
}
private Object configurable;
}

4. Then there's the variation that allows for changing configuration to
vary with common test bodies from test to test only running appropriate
tests for each configuration:

public class TheTests extends TestCase {
protected doConfigurableTestOne(Object thing) {
// Do tests on thing
}
protected doConfigurableTestTwo(Object thing) {
// Do tests on thing
}
public Object getConfigurationOne() {
return // Object in configuration one
}
public Object getConfigurationTwo() {
return // Object in configuration one
}

public testOneWithConfigurationOne() {
Object testedThing = getConfigurationOne();
doConfigurableTestOne(testedThing);
}
public testOneWithConfigurationTwo() {
Object testedThing = getConfigurationTwo();
doConfigurableTestOne(testedThing);
}
public testTwoWithConfigurationOne() {
Object testedThing = getConfigurationOne();
doConfigurableTestTwo(testedThing);
}
// Omit testTwoWithConfigurationTwo as it doesn't make sense
}

and so on.....

All depends on the circumstances and personal preference. Be careful
not to abuse #4, it's a tad brittle.

Regards,

Rob
